Expectation1: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation1: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I was sitting at my desk, reviewing the calendar, when the phone rang. It was a young couple, voices trembling with excitement, asking if I could officiate their wedding next spring. I could hear the hope in their words, the trust they placed in me to guide them through one of life’s sacred moments. I promised to check my schedule and get back to them soon. As I hung up, my phone buzzed again—this time, a producer from a major news network. They needed me on air, now, to counter a wave of misinformation about the cause I’ve poured my heart into. My activist side knew how crucial this moment was; the community was counting on me to speak truth, to educate, to defend. But as a rabbi, I also knew the importance of being present for my congregants, of honoring commitments, even those not yet set in stone. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full presence, each unwilling to wait. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between two callings, unsure which to answer first.
